title: 115_hr2728
content: The Act titled "Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017" requires labeling for cleaning products. The Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 mandates that cleaning products must have a label listing all ingredients in descending order of predominance by weight, including dyes, fragrances, and preservatives. Ingredients constituting less than 1 percent may be listed at the end in any order. The Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 requires cleaning products to list all ingredients, including CAS Registry Numbers and explanations of their purpose, in English, Spanish, and other necessary languages to inform users in the United States. Nonconforming products may face consequences under the jurisdiction of the Commission. The Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 mandates that non-compliant products will be treated as hazardous substances under the Federal Hazardous Substances Act or as products in violation of rules under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. The Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 mandates that non-compliant products will be treated as hazardous substances under existing labeling requirements, and the Consumer Product Safety Commission will issue regulations for standardized ingredient listing within a year of the Act's enactment. The Cleaning Product Labeling Act of 2017 requires standardized ingredient listing on product labels and websites to ensure compliance and effective enforcement. Occupational Safety and Health Administration will issue regulations within a year to achieve this goal. The Act requires standardized ingredient listing on product labels and websites for compliance and enforcement. It does not affect the jurisdiction of the Commission or the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. SEC. 3. PUBLIC RIGHT TO KNOW PETITION. Any person can submit a petition to the agency alleging non-compliance with labeling requirements for cleaning products. The agency must notify the petitioner within 30 days and investigate the claims within 180 days. If the claims are valid, enforcement actions will be taken. The agency can also issue regulations as needed. The agency can issue regulations requiring petitions to include a reasonable evidentiary basis for claims made. SEC. 4. RELATIONSHIP TO STATE LAWS. This Act does not override State regulations unless compliance with both this Act and State regulations is impossible. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "agency of jurisdiction" refers to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Commission for cleaning products. An "air care product" is a mixture of chemicals used to clean and freshen indoor air. An "automotive product" is a chemically formulated consumer product designed for vehicles. A cleaning product is a chemically formulated consumer product used for cleaning purposes, excluding drugs, cosmetics, and pesticides. The term "ingredient" in cleaning products refers to chemicals intentionally added for technical or functional effects, including breakdown products and individual components of fragrances or preservatives. The term "incidental ingredient" in cleaning products refers to chemicals present for technical or functional effects, including substances added during processing, components of other chemicals, and contaminants that may form over time. The term "polish or floor maintenance product" refers to consumer products designed to polish, protect, or maintain various surfaces. The term "Secretary of Labor" refers to the Secretary of Labor, specifically the Assistant Secretary of Labor for Occupational Safety and Health.
